(a) Wrong. Magnetic field lines can never emanate from a point, as shown in figure. Over any closed surface, the net flux of B must always be zero, i.e., pictorially as many field lines should seem to enter the surface as the number of lines leaving it. The field lines shown, in fact, represent electric field of a long positively charged wire. The correct magnetic field lines are circling the straight conductor, as described in Chapter 4.

(b) Wrong.
summary: This text discusses the concept of magnetic field lines, refuting incorrect depictions of magnetic field around a long straight wire where magnetic field lines are supposed to emanate from a point, ensuring consistency with the law that the net flux of the magnetic field over any closed surface must always be zero.
hypothetical_questions: Why can magnetic field lines never emanate from a point according to Ampere's law?
How does the net flux of magnetic field lines across any closed surface signify the magnetic field's behavior?
Differentiate between magnetic and electric fields and their properties.
